input:
Lecture 1

Overfitting: fitting too closely to the data, and not giving a more general result. It is undesirable in ML

Spurious Correlation: when data appears to be related, but isn’t
ie: a cow is always in a green background, but when it’s in a different background, AI assumes it’s not a cow.

Train/Validation/Test Split:
purpose: prevent overfitting, generalizes well to new unseen data
training set: used to train the model; model learns relationship between features (input variable) and target (output variable). usually 60-80% of data.
validation set: used to select the best performing model in the training process. Checks how well model is performing, smaller portion of data (10-20% of data)
test set: provides final evaluation, only used once. (10-20% of data)
note: never train on the test set, gauge performance on validation set

Overfitting vs Underfitting:
overfitting: trained too well, causing it to perform poorly on new data
underfitting: cannot capture pattern of data, performs poorly on all data
how to tell overfitting: low train loss, high validation loss

Lecture 1

Overfitting: fitting too closely to the data, and not giving a more general result. It is undesirable in ML

Spurious Correlation: when data appears to be related, but isn’t
ie: a cow is always in a green background, but when it’s in a different background, AI assumes it’s not a cow.

Train/Validation/Test Split:

validation set: used to select the best performing model in the training process. Checks how well model is performing, smaller portion of data (10-20% of data)
test set: provides final evaluation, only used once. (10-20% of data)
note: never train on the test set, gauge performance on validation set

Overfitting vs Underfitting:
overfitting: trained too well, causing it to perform poorly on new data
underfitting: cannot capture pattern of data, performs poorly on all data
how to tell overfitting: low train loss, high validation loss

Scaling: 
neural networks (NN): takes in a list of numbers, outputs a list of numbers.
kind of like a really complicated math function
NNs scale very well - larger by adding more weights, learns data effectively

Probability Distributions(PD) : pairs up events with likelihood of them occurring
probabilities all have to add up to 1
Samping: picking one event according to its likelihood

Generative Models (GM): estimate of a probability distribution
GM of a 6-sided die would assign probability to each # on the die
GMs can take in sequential data - assigning probabilities to sequences
instead of probs for 1, 2, 3… (1, 1, 1, 1), (1, 1, 1, 2) etc…

Autoregressive Models: a generative model that takes a sequence of input and produces a PD over the next token in the sequence; example: (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6,??)
problem: longer sequences = tons of possible sequences
